thread.title: Montgomery: Undercover officers 'may be on hand' at pot expo
thread.title_full: Montgomery: Undercover officers 'may be on hand' at pot expo

title: Montgomery: Undercover officers 'may be on hand' at pot expo
text:
Montgomery: Undercover operatives 'may be on hand' during marijuana expo in Phoenix Maricopa County Attorney Bill Montgomery reminds visitors that recreational marijuana use is illegal in Arizona. Post to Facebook Montgomery: Undercover operatives 'may be on hand' during marijuana expo in Phoenix Maricopa County Attorney Bill Montgomery reminds visitors that recreational marijuana use is illegal in Arizona. Check out this story on azcentral.com: http://azc.cc/1LBZfWB Cancel Send A link has been sent to your friend's email address. Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. 2 Yvonne Wingett Sanchez , The Republic | azcentral.com 10:20 p.m. MST October 17, 2015 Political Insider: Political races including a triathalon 
Maricopa County Attorney Bill Montgomery has put visitors traveling to Phoenix for an upcoming marijuana business expo on notice that recreational use of the drug is not legal in Arizona. 
Montgomery, a vocal opponent of cannabis for medical and recreational purposes, suggested law enforcement may try to crack down on illicit activities. No marijuana will be on hand at the Southwest Cannabis Conference and Expo at the Phoenix Convention Center, which starts Oct. 26, a person connected to the expo told The Arizona Republic on Wednesday. 
Instead, the expo will feature related products, seminars and job fair. It is designed for industry experts. 
Montgomery's warning came during a news conference in which he gave a presentation about drug abuse. 
Letter writer Patrice Reis observes: "There is rampant rhetoric and misinformation regarding marijuana use." (Photo: Jeff Chiu, AP) 
"Just a polite warning to folks traveling here that recreational marijuana is not legal here in Arizona, so folks who are traveling from out of state and may be engaged in business transactions at the Phoenix Convention Center, you could be violating state and federal laws when it comes to trafficking in marijuana, and I can't confirm or deny whether or not local and federal law enforcement may be on hand in an undercover capacity," he said. "So welcome to Phoenix, enjoy your stay. But be careful." 
Arizonans legalized marijuana during the 2010 election for medicinal purposes only. Supporters of legalizing it for recreational use are gathering signatures to try to put the issue before voters in 2016. 
Under the proposed Regulation and Taxation of Marijuana Act, adults 21 and older could possess up to 1 ounce of marijuana and grow up to six plants in their homes without obtaining licenses, as long as the plants were in a secure area. The initiative also would create a distribution system similar to Coloradoâ€™s, where licensed businesses produce and sell marijuana, and pay a 15 percent tax on retail sales to be allocated to education and public health. 
On Friday, expo staffers sent 23 tickets to the expo to Montgomery, and invited him to attend. Montgomery told The Republic he had not yet seen the tickets, but would not attend the event. 
"I'll politely decline to avoid becoming a fact-finding witness," he said. 
Follow the reporter on Twitter @yvonnewingett and reach her at 602-444-4712 or yvonne.wingett@arizonarepublic.com Read or Share this story: http://azc.cc/1LBZfWB Most Popular
